data.title: Code editor trackpad scroll speed too fast and pan is too sensitive
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Macbook Pro Mac OS 10.12
All Godot versions

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
1. Code editor trackpad scroll speed is way too fast
2. The L/R pan is too sensitive, when scrolling up and down it also scrolls right - there should be a threshold set.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open some code and scroll multiple lines.

data.title: Godot 3.0 concerns
data.body:
I'm in the middle of the development of a game and I'd like to know how the Godot 3.0 project is going to be managed.

What I know/believe;
- a) Godot 2.2 is going to be skipped in favor of Godot 3.0.
- b) Godot 3.0 will be based on OpenGL ES 3.
- c) Godot 3.0 will break compatibility with 2.x at various levels (scripting, shaders, etc.).

Godot current master branch currently features pretty much everything I need, but during the lifetime of my project I will probably need to update some things (support for upcoming Android/iOS releases, engine bugfixes, etc.).

I can deal with adapting my project to 3.0 as long as no very complex changes are needed at the scene and script levels, but rewriting shaders and specially loosing compatibility with OpenGL 2 are big concerns for me.

Are these my only options?:
- Keep using 2.1 custom builds and hope no engine or platform support updates are needed.
- Switch to 3.0, readapt, rewrite shaders, etc. and loose support for OpenGL ES 2.

data.title: Crash when custom subclass that inherits from `Reference` and overrides `_notification` and receives notification
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

macOS 10.11.6 - v2.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

Created subclass, overrides `_notification`. When the instance should be sent `NOTIFICATION_PREDELETE` (the only notification Reference gets?)  and freed the game crashes.

Expected to receive notification.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create subclass of `Reference` and override `_notification`
- Create an instance. 
- Set it to null, or let go out of scope. 
- Then crash.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

[godot-ref-test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/520762/godot-ref-test.zip)

data.title: Fix #5959, contrasting texture for toggled button
data.body: As no one proposed fix to #5959 I think my version can be used for toggle buttons until there's nothing better. Maybe it could still get into 2.1.1

data.title: New load icon, removed unused open icon
data.body:
In my opinion current load icon is not good enough, sometimes at first glance I mistake it with save, as it is solid and has right top corner cut off (especially when save icon is grayed out).

Also I've removed open icon as it was only copy of load icon and was unused.

data.title: Remove unnecessary parentheses

data.title: Allow turning off zero-padding for line numbers
data.body:
Zero-padded line numbers result in too much visual noise making it harder than necessary to locate lines by sight to fix errors.

This PR allows the user to choose if he wants zero-padding or not (just right-aligned line numbers).

I've dared setting zero-padding disabled as the default. If this is controversial, I can change it.

data.title: Documentation of RPC-related methods and classes
data.body:
Obviously RPC needs to be documented. It's surprisingly hard to do without images...
Anyway, I'm having a hard time understanding `rpc_config` and `rset_config` methods. Since we ~~can define multiple functions with different rpc rules (master slave sync remote)... what does `rpc_config` actually do?~~ (nope, we can't) The sourcecode seems to overwrite a method's `RPC_MODE_*`, which I can't think of use for...
- [x] Basic SceneTree and NetworkedMultiplayerENet connection
- [x] Describe basic rpc and rset functions
- [x] Describe `*_config` functions

Anyway, suggestions and feedback greatly appreciated. Is the content understandable?

data.title: Fix Script Editor drawing over Dialogs.
data.body:
Resets the z-index when focus is lost and the completion is shown.

Fixes #6769 

Also relevant for the 2.1 branch ( @akien-mga )

data.title: Revise serial naming behavior
data.body:
Fixes #6768.

Also tries to be more user-friendly: in case the original node name ended in `separator + 0` (explicit user intent of zero-based counting) the first attempt at a non-colliding name will be `separator + 1`.

If the original name has no a `separator + n` trailer, the next attempt will be `separator + 2`, like the classic behavior.

I take the opportunity to ask here:
If the setting for separator was set to none and a node name naturally ended with a number (either a node type or a character name like `R2D2`), the algorithm would do a unnatural serial naming: `R2D3`, `R2D4`, etc. That was the case even before my modifications IIRC. Then the question is: should the setting for no separator be dropped to avoid such scenarios or instead should we let the user understand what is happening (that Godot has not AI for disambiguating)?

data.title: Allow step for integer properties
data.body:
If step is not provided in the hint string, it defaults to 1 so if doesn't affect existent properties.

I don't know why this is not already enabled. I've checked and it's allowed only for reals since the beginning of the repository. Any strong reason?

…Plus a small readability fix since lack of both indentation and braces generates confusion.

data.title: Make text column numbers one-based
data.body:
It has always seem strange to me that Godot reports text locations with a one-based line number and zero-based column number.

I think that by also making the column numbers one-based makes for a **more consistent** experience, yet **friendlier** (Godot strives to be a friendly environment) and more **universal** (text editors universally count lines from one).

This PR covers cursor location and error locations for both GDScript and shader editors. Not completely sure if these are all the cases.

data.title: Fix shader tokenizer-parser reporting wrong error location
data.body: Keeping the commented line, adapted to the new flow, should it be needed sometime.

data.title: Gles3
Undoing a change in a texture region won't reflect in the region editor.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu Linux 16.04, Godot version fea1fb0925142c3279fd3afaf27e80e78cd2e1e8

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Changing a texture region and then undoing it won't change the selection rectangle. Closing and opening the region editor again or changing to other tools in the bottom dock (animation editor/debugger/output) won't reflect the change as well. Only changing to another scene and back will show the change.
This could be misleading as it makes it seem like region changes aren't being undone unless one is aware of this bug.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open a texture region editor and click somewhere to change the current region, then undo. Change to other tools in the bottom dock and back and it will still show the changes before undo. Change to another scene and return to the one with the undone region, now it refreshes properly.

data.title: Some scenes marked as changed just by switching to them in the editor
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu Linux 16.04, Godot version fea1fb0925142c3279fd3afaf27e80e78cd2e1e8

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Some scenes are somehow marked as changed simply by switching to them as seen in this small video [http://kuuv.io/i/8PTa8Um.mp4](http://kuuv.io/i/8PTa8Um.mp4)

This could be related to an animationplayer being present in the scene even if it's not playing. While not a huge issue by itself, it can lead to minor annoyances like displacing tabs out of view when there are few opened due to the size difference incurred by the (*) mark, and it's an undoable change, meaning a bunch of such changes could potentially push out important stuff out of the undo stack.
On a less technical note, it's slightly bothersome, as it's a change that's not known for no apparent reason.

**Steps to reproduce:**
I can only seem to reproduce it with scenes containing animation players, regardless of their playing state. Changing back and forth to a scene _without_ an animationplayer seems to not trigger it, but jumping to a different scene _with_ an animationplayer does, and any consecutive scenes with.

data.title: Adding a "end" keyword at the end of func / loop/ if
data.body:
Hi I'm Nio Kasgami,

I have to say I'm happy on how you guys made a such nice OOP languages for the engine 
Easy to grasp the concept, yet powerful for doing what I want.

Although, this would be maybe just a taste but when I do if or function I'm used to having a closure symbol for show that my method or condition stop here. (example "{}" from standart C like languages or "end" from ruby/ lua).

This not like super problematic but I'm used to see them and find them more clean.

Could it be possible to add the **optional** possibility to add a end keyword to func block and condition, loop? 

thanks for your further answer!

data.title: Node names reject a single "1" at the end of their name.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 16.10, 64b
Godot fea1fb0925142c3279fd3afaf27e80e78cd2e1e8

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I had a scene with its parent node named "BattleChoice1" which was instanced into another scene along with a "BattleChoice2" node. But suddenly and without any interaction it was renamed "BattleChoice" and any attempts to change it back proved futile. From renaming it in the editor to altering the tscn scene.
![](http://i.imgur.com/r9kAkJD.gif)

Those 2 scenes are the only ones with "BattleChoice" names, and there's no possible way to change it back to "BattleChoice1". I changed the nodepaths appropriately to suit the change, but it's still weird and I never touched the scene itself (I was editing a different scene at the time and when running a reference turned out null for no apparent reason).

**Steps to reproduce:**
Given the strange circumstances I can't provide reproduction steps, and since it's a component in a relatively large project I can't quite link to the entire project (I got the source on github but it's one day old, at https://github.com/hetdegon/VaultCityRaiders ,so it might not be suitable to reproduce).

_Alternately, the editor got possessed by a ghost, but we are people of science here._

data.title: Ability to add custom icons to scenes.
data.body:
Ability to add custom icons to scenes so that when you link in a scene instead of the icon of the root node you get the custom icon.

Why do we need this? Because when you link in your player or some other instance it can be hard to tell the difference between them if thay have the same root node, this would just help to make you scenes more readable and clean.

Of course i dont know if this would slow down the editor as i dont know how icons are handled in the editor.

data.title: [Bug] Zooming in Visual Script Editor
data.body:
Godot Engine v.2.2.alpha.custom_build on Linux Mint 18 Mate x86-64

After zooming it happens:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5412322/19224917/f4afa65e-8ea8-11e6-881d-580e2fda8776.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5412322/19224945/9b4a72fa-8ea9-11e6-8b0b-97239913319d.png)
No matter approximation or distancing it - all nodes visually "torn" and move along the coordinate axes.

At a scale of 1:1, everything returns to normal.

data.title: Custom-made resource types cannot be used in export statement
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 - Godot 2.1 Stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Created a custom resource type as a plugin and attempted to `export(CustomResource)`, which raises `error(17,7): Export hint not a type or resource.`

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a plugin which defines a custom resource type. `add_custom_type` like the plugins tutorial shows (Specifically, `add_custom_type("Name", "Resource", preload("plugin_source.gd"), preload("icon.png"))`). The new type will appear in the "create resource" menu, but attempting to `export(CustomResourceName)` will raise the error.

**Link to minimal example project**:
[Custom Resource (2.1s).zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/518589/Custom.Resource.2.1s.zip)

Can't build Godot for HTML5 (from Windows)
data.body:
Following [this issue](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/6755), I tried to compile for HTML5 using commit https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/9012dfb8eb7276e29d567d27b49f6fea317bd83c.

I'm using [this build script](https://gist.github.com/Calinou/f61ec28ffc1782dd6eb2dc1e3427c907) which used to work just fine. I think it broke about 2 weeks ago, but I'm not entirely sure.

```
scons: Reading SConscript files ...

scons: *** Multiple ways to build the same target were specified for: main.javascript.opt.bc  (from ['main.cpp'] and from ['input_default.javascript.opt.bc', 'main.javascript.opt.bc', 'performance.javascript.opt.bc'])
File "C:\Users\Hugo\Documents\Git\godot\main\SCsub", line 8, in <module>
```

data.title: Vector2i and Vector3i in core?
data.body:
I am writing a new experimental module which needs to manipulate data indexed by integer coordinates. I also need to use spatial hash on that, so I went on creating a Vector3i structure to hold a 3D integer position that can also serve as key in dictionaries.

However it enters in conflict [with another module I made](https://github.com/Zylann/godot_voxel/blob/master/vector3i.h). I could use a different name or use a namespace, but it feels silly because I basically copy/paste the existing implementation.

Would it be better if we had a Vector2i and Vector3i structure built-in the core?

data.title: Gradle fails building on Linux
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Mageia 6 x86_64, NDK r11c, SDK last updated in July
Current master branch (616ddbd)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Building the Godot lib for both release and debug targets work fine, but gradle fails:

```
$ ./gradlew build
Incremental java compilation is an incubating feature.
:preBuild UP-TO-DATE

```
